title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children." This chapter aims to protect unborn children under Section 1841. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," introduces a new chapter in Title 18 of the United States Code, called "Protection of Unborn Children." This chapter addresses conduct that causes harm or death to a child in utero, creating a separate offense with specific punishments. It does not require proof of knowledge about the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. If the conduct intentionally kills the unborn child, harsher penalties apply. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a new chapter in Title 18 of the United States Code, addressing harm or death to a child in utero. The act creates a separate offense with specific punishments, including harsher penalties if the conduct intentionally kills the unborn child. The death penalty is not imposed for offenses under this section. The act references various sections of the U.S. Code for enforcement. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a new chapter in Title 18 of the United States Code, addressing harm or death to a child in utero. The act references specific sections of the U.S. Code for enforcement, including sections related to the Controlled Substances Act and the Atomic Energy Act. It clarifies that prosecution is not permitted for certain actions related to abortion or medical treatment of pregnant women or their unborn children. The act defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, known as "Laci and Conner's Law," protects unborn children by amending the Uniform Code of Military Justice to include a new section on death or injury of an unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice to establish separate offenses for causing death or bodily injury to a child in utero. Offenses under this section do not require proof of knowledge of pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. Intentional killing of the unborn child results in different punishment under specific sections of the law. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes separate offenses for causing death or bodily injury to an unborn child. The law specifies punishment for intentionally killing or attempting to kill the unborn child, without imposing the death penalty. Prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," prohibits prosecution for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, and any woman with respect to her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a child in utero, a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development.
